A01:2021.name: Broken Access Control
A01:2021.description: Access control enforces policy such that users cannot act outside of their intended permissions
checks: Enforce least privilege and deny-by-default
Implement access control checks on server-side
Invalidate JWT tokens on logout
Rate-limit API and controller access
Disable directory listing, ensure metadata files (.git, .env) not accessible
Log access control failures, alert on suspicious patterns
Test: Can users access resources they shouldn't?
Test: Can users escalate privileges?

A02:2021.name: Cryptographic Failures
A02:2021.description: Failures related to cryptography which often lead to exposure of sensitive data
checks: Classify data (PII, credentials, health, financial) and apply appropriate controls
Encrypt data at rest and in transit (TLS 1.2+, disable older protocols)
Use strong, up-to-date encryption algorithms (AES-256, no MD5/SHA1 for security)
Proper key management (rotate, store securely, never hardcode)
Disable caching for sensitive data responses
Test: Are passwords/secrets transmitted over HTTP?
Test: Are secrets stored in plaintext?

A03:2021.name: Injection
A03:2021.description: Application is vulnerable to injection when user-supplied data is not validated, filtered, or sanitized
checks: Use parameterized queries, ORMs, or prepared statements
Validate and sanitize all user input (allow-list validation preferred)
Use LIMIT and SQL controls to prevent mass disclosure
For AI/LLM: validate prompts, sanitize model inputs/outputs, implement prompt injection defenses
Escape special characters in queries and commands
Test: SQL injection, command injection, LDAP injection
Test: Prompt injection (for AI/LLM applications)

A04:2021.name: Insecure Design
A04:2021.description: Risks related to design and architectural flaws, missing or ineffective control design
checks: Threat modeling during design phase
Secure design patterns (defense-in-depth, fail-safe defaults)
Segregate tenants robustly in multi-tenant systems
Limit resource consumption per user/tenant
Review architecture with security expert before implementation
Test: Business logic flaws, race conditions
Test: Privilege escalation through design flaws

A05:2021.name: Security Misconfiguration
A05:2021.description: Application might be vulnerable if it is missing security hardening or has improperly configured permissions
checks: Repeatable hardening process (IaC, automated config)
Minimal platform (remove unused features, frameworks, components)
Review cloud storage permissions (S3 buckets, blob storage)
Disable default accounts and passwords
Error messages don't leak sensitive information (stack traces, DB errors)
Keep security patches up-to-date (automated where possible)
Test: Default credentials work?
Test: Stack traces exposed?
Test: Open ports/services?

A06:2021.name: Vulnerable and Outdated Components
A06:2021.description: Using components with known vulnerabilities may undermine application defenses
checks: Inventory all components (packages, libraries, containers, OS)
Remove unused dependencies and features
Monitor for vulnerabilities (Dependabot, Snyk, npm audit, pip-audit)
Subscribe to security bulletins for components in use
Obtain components from official sources over secure links
Prefer signed packages with strong maintainer reputation
Test: Run npm audit, pip-audit, or equivalent regularly

A07:2021.name: Identification and Authentication Failures
A07:2021.description: Confirmation of the user's identity, authentication, and session management is critical
checks: Implement MFA where possible
No default credentials shipped with application
Weak password checks (block common passwords, enforce complexity)
Credential stuffing, brute force, automated attack protections (rate limiting, CAPTCHA)
Secure session management (random IDs, HTTPOnly, Secure, SameSite cookies)
Invalidate sessions on logout
Use established auth libraries (OAuth 2.1, OpenID Connect), avoid custom crypto
Test: Brute force login, credential stuffing
Test: Session fixation

A08:2021.name: Software and Data Integrity Failures
A08:2021.description: Code and infrastructure that does not protect against integrity violations
checks: Use digital signatures to verify software/data integrity
Verify dependencies from trusted repos (NPM, PyPI with integrity hashes)
Review CI/CD pipeline security (restrict permissions, audit changes)
Implement auto-update mechanisms with integrity verification
Ensure untrusted data doesn't flow into deserialization without validation
Test: Can attacker modify build artifacts?
Test: Inject malicious dependencies?

A09:2021.name: Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
A09:2021.description: Without logging and monitoring, breaches cannot be detected
checks: Log authentication, authorization, input validation failures
Structured logging with context (user ID, IP, timestamp, action)
Logs stored securely, protected from tampering
High-value transactions have audit trail with integrity controls
Effective monitoring and alerting (abnormal behavior, suspicious patterns)
Incident response plan in place
Test: Are failed logins logged?
Test: Can you detect attack patterns?

A10:2021.name: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
A10:2021.description: SSRF flaws occur when application fetches a remote resource without validating the user-supplied URL
checks: Sanitize and validate all client-supplied URL data
Enforce URL schema, port, and destination with allow-list
Disable HTTP redirections
Don't send raw responses to clients
Network segmentation to reduce SSRF impact
Test: Can attacker make server fetch internal resources?
Test: Access metadata endpoints (169.254.169.254)?

AI/MCP.name: AI/MCP Specific Security
AI/MCP.description: Security considerations for AI/LLM applications and MCP servers
checks: Prompt Injection: Validate and sanitize all user inputs before sending to LLM
Prompt Injection: Use instruction/data separation patterns
Prompt Injection: Implement output validation and filtering
Prompt Injection: Monitor for suspicious patterns (jailbreak attempts)
MCP Server: Authenticate all MCP client connections
MCP Server: Validate tool parameters and resource URIs
MCP Server: Implement rate limiting per client
MCP Server: Audit logging for all tool invocations
MCP Server: Principle of least privilege for tool capabilities
MCP Server: Validate sampling requests don't leak sensitive data
Data Privacy: Never send PII to external LLM APIs without consent
Data Privacy: Implement data anonymization/pseudonymization
Data Privacy: Respect data retention policies
Data Privacy: Clear audit trail of what data was sent to which models
